ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

PESIARAN KELILING
(Traffic Arrangements)


    1. Mr S. V. Lingam asked the Deputy Prime Minister whether he will give early consideration to (a) making Pesiaran Keliling a one-way street; (b) permitting the extension of bus services into the Macpherson Housing Estate; and (c) the parking of vehicles on one side only of Pesiaran Keliling.

    The Minister of State for the Prime Minister's Department (Tuan Haji Yaacob Bin Mohamed) (for the Deputy Prime Minister)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, in answer to (a) , entry into Macpherson Housing Estate and Pesiaran Keliling is via Jalan Merpati and exit via Mattar Road. Both these approach and exit roads are made into one-way streets because of their narrowness. Mattar Road is 18 feet wide and Jalan Merpati 22 feet wide.

    Pesiaran Keliling, however, is 31 feet wide and the total distance is 1.1 miles round the Estate from its commencement at its junction with Jalan Merpati. This road was constructed sufficiently wide enough to carry two-way traffic. If this road were to be converted into one-way, it will be causing undue hardship and unnecessary inconvenience to the residents in this Housing Estate.

    In answer to (b) , the Omnibus Services Licensing Authority has approved extensions of bus services into the Macpherson Housing Estate. The Omni-bus Services Licensing Authority has approved two S.T.C. bus services which would operate in this Housing Estate. The first is a deviation of part of S.T.C. Service No. 12, to be known as Service No. 12A, from Macpherson Housing Estate via Jalan Besar, New Bridge Road/North Bridge Road to Shenton Way. The second is an extension of S.T.C. Service No. 9 from Shenton Way via Alexandra Road, Tanglin Road, Orchard Road and Serangoon Road to Macpherson Estate.

    The Omnibus Services Licensing Authority also has before it two applications from the Tay Koh Yat Bus Co. Ltd. to deviate its Service No. 11 from the junction of Aljunied Road/Geylang

Column: 104

Road to the junction of Upper Serangoon Road/Woodsville Circus, and Service No. 12 from the junction of Aljunied Road/Geylang Road to the junction of Macpherson Road/Woodsville Circus into Macpherson Estate. These two applications were advertised in the local Press on 13th May, 1966 and will be considered by the Omnibus Services Licensing Authority one month after their publication.

    In answer to (c) , it is proposed to draw a continuous white line along Pesiaran Keliling, Jalan Pipit and Jalan Balam. This will ensure that no vehicles are parked along this road and there would be a smooth flow of traffic. Sufficient car parks and parking bays have been provided in this housing estate to cater for the residents. The car parks and parking bays are now occupied by unlicensed hawkers, causing the owners of motor cars to park their vehicles on the road proper. This has created some confusion along Pesiaran Keliling, particularly at its junction with Jalan Merpati. Once the hawkers are removed to the market, which has been completed recently, the car parks and parking bays could be used for the purpose for which they are constructed. It will not, therefore, be necessary for residents to park their vehicles on the road proper.

APPLICANTS FOR DRIVING LICENCES
(Change of Parking Test Site)


    2. Mr P. Govindaswamy asked the Deputy Prime Minister whether arrangements will be made for the parking test of applicants for driving licences, carried out on the roadway in front of the new community centre under construction behind the Traffic Police Office at Maxwell Road, to be conducted at some other place when the community centre is completed.

    Tuan Haji Yaacob (for the Deputy Prime Minister)(In Malay): Most of the activities at a community centre take place after office hours and on weekends or public holidays. Therefore, driving tests conducted on the road in front of the community centre should not in any way interfere with its activities. Even

Column: 105

the present construction work carried out in the day-time is not affected at all by the driving tests.

    Mr Govindaswamy (Anson)(In Tamil): There is a school erected at the place where the community centre is situated now, and school children may be playing in the field in future. At the time when the tests are taken there, the children will not be able to take a short cut. That is why I say that it is necessary to change the venue.

    Mr Speaker: What is the question? Is there a supplementary question which the Member wants to ask?

    Mr Govindaswamy(In Tamil): The Minister has replied that there is no interference at that place. But I say that when the school is erected, the school children will be going to the playground and I think that it is not a proper place to carry out the tests.

    Mr Speaker: It is not a supplementary question, but if the Minister of State wishes to answer what is troubling the hon. Member, he may do so. The hon. Member is worried about children crossing the street.

    Tuan Haji Yaacob(In Malay): The question is about the erection of a community centre. If it is a question of the erection of a school, then that is another question completely.

APPLICANTS FOR DRIVING LICENCES
(Use of Tamil Language for Highway Code Test)


    3. Mr S. V. Lingam asked the Deputy Prime Minister whether complaints made in the Tamil dailies about not using the Tamil language for the Highway Code Test for the issue of driving licences were brought to his attention, and whether he will appoint persons to conduct the Highway Code Test in Tamil also, as it is done in Malay, Mandarin and English.

    Tuan Haji Yaacob (for the Deputy Prime Minister)(In Malay): Mr Speaker,

Column: 106

Sir, in October 1965, 3,384 persons took the Highway Code test of whom 108 were Tamils. In May 1966, 3,519 persons took this test of whom 105 were Tamils. This works out roughly at three per cent as being Tamil-speaking testees, and most of them were also able to speak either English or Malay.

    There are at present two Senior Testers, both Chinese, and 18 testers, of whom 13 are Chinese, two Eurasians, one Malay, one Singhalese and one Tamil. The number of Tamils at the moment is small. When the number justifies it, more Tamil testers will be employed and the use of Tamil will be permitted.

    Testees for Highway Code tests are assigned to various testers so that testees cannot choose the tester nor the tester his testees. If the testee fails his test, a different tester is assigned to him for his next test. It would be a departure from this fair and reasonable practice for the Tamil tester to test Tamil testees only.

COMMUNITY CENTRE IN RACE COURSE ROAD


    4. Mr S. Rajoo asked the Minister of Defence if he will consider the building of a community centre on the children's playground opposite No. 130 Race Course Road.

    The Minister of State of Defence (Mr Wee Toon Boon) (for the Minister of Defence): Mr Speaker, Sir, the proposed site is barely 800 yards from the Pek Kio Community Centre. The Minister therefore will not consider building a community centre there both for this reason and because it is wrong to deprive children of their playground.

    The Minister had, on a previous occasion, reminded hon. Members that the policy of the People's Association is to improve the standard and scope of activities of community centres rather than build new ones. To this end, Management Committees have been established to direct activities in community centres. These Management Committees have local leaders and it

Column: 107

is important that Members of Parliament who are advisers to these Management Committees keep in close touch with them and attend their monthly meetings.

STATISTICS OF HOSPITAL BED
ACCOMMODATION AND
REQUEST FOR EMERGENCY UNIT
AT THOMSON ROAD HOSPITAL


    5. Mr P. Govindaswamy asked the Minister for Health (a) how many beds there are in each hospital, giving separate figures for beds in the different classes, where applicable; (b) whether the number of beds in each type of hospital is adequate to meet present needs; (c) whether there is a programme for expansion of hospital bed accommodation to meet future needs, and if he will give details; and (d) if he will consider setting up an emergency unit at the Thomson Road Hospital for the treatment of casualties.

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, in reply to the first part of question (a) , there are 14 Government hospitals in Singapore with a total of 6,797 staffed beds at present, of which the majority 6,433 or 90 per cent are free of charge (i.e. 'C' Class). There are 249 'B' Class beds at a charge of $12 per day and 115 'A' Class beds at a charge of $30 per day or $40 per day, if air-conditioned.

    As the hon. Member has asked for details of the number of beds in each hospital, and their classification as well, I am therefore submitting the details in a separate schedule for tabling and circulation instead.

    With regard to (b) , as a general rule, it can reasonably be said that the present bed capacity in Government hospitals as a whole are adequate, but the following three are either congested or under great pressure, namely, Woodbridge Hospital, Outram Road General Hospital and Kandang Kerbau Hospital.

    Before answering (c) of the question on proposed programme of expansion, may I, Sir, indicate certain steps which have already been taken to lessen the

Column: 108

present congestion or pressures of the three named hospitals?

    Firstly, in the case of Woodbridge Hospital, thanks to the efficacy of modern drugs and in accordance with modern practice, it has been possible for more and more patients to be discharged from hospital and to continue treatment in what are known as Day Centres. Secondly, as Trafalgar Home, which adjoins Woodbridge Hospital, is only half-full, a section of Trafalgar Home is now being renovated and converted for the transfer of the chronically sick from Woodbridge Hospital, in order to relieve the congestion at the latter hospital.

    In the case of Outram Road General Hospital, it has been necessary to alleviate the pressure of numbers by a quicker turnover of patients and the average length of stay of patients is around nine days per patient. It is agreed that this is not an ideal method, but has to be resorted to until such time as more hospitals can be built and, what is even more important, more staff, i.e, doctors, nurses and technicians, and equipment are available.

    An effort, however, has already been made to relieve the pressures on Outram Road General Hospital with the setting up of two surgical theatres in Thomson Road Hospital in January 1965, thus converting it into Singapore's second General Hospital.

    Two effective steps have already been taken to relieve the pressure in Kandang Kerbau Hospital. In order to encourage greater use of our Free Domiciliary Midwifery service, a nominal charge of $10 was levied for 'C' Class patients from December 1964. Next, Government has given full publicity for some time regarding the need to offer Singapore mothers the latest techniques in Family Planning and have, in fact, established a Family Planning and Population Board in January this year to implement a 5-Year Family Planning programme in all Maternal and Child Health Centres.

    Both these measures, I am glad to say, have shown immediate and heartening results. Out of a total of 58,217

Column: 109

births in Singapore in 1964, there was a peak number of deliveries in Kandang Kerbau Hospital at 39,598. Last year, 1965, the total number of deliveries in Singapore fell to 55,736, and for the first time Kandang Kerbau Hospital also showed a drop in its deliveries at 38,849.

    As for the response to Family Planning under the auspices of the Family Planning and Population Board, I am pleased to say that for the first 5 months of this year, a total of 15,718 mothers are now receiving family planning assistance, made up of 4,691 new cases and the balance being former Singapore Family Planning Association cases.

    As for future plans of expansion, firstly, we intend to build more Day Centres for the mentally ill; secondly,

Column: 110

    In respect of (d) of the question under reply, Sir, Thomson Road General Hospital has a Casualty and Emergency Unit with effect from July 1965 but limited to admission of casualties and accident cases between the hours of 8.30 in the morning and 3.00 in the afternoon. It is planned to operate this Emergency Unit on a 24-hour basis as soon as nursing staff are available to man it.

ALSAGOFF ESTATE
(Allocation of house numbers)


    6. Inche Mohd. Ariff Bin Suradi asked the Minister for Finance whether the Government will give house numbers to the houses built before 1st April, 1960, in Alsagoff Estate whose house owners are paying ground rent to the landlords or their agents.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance (Mr S. Ramaswamy) (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, when applications for house numbers are made to the Comptroller of Property Tax, who has the authority for the issue of house numbers in the Republic, house numbers will be issued, where the applicants produce either a temporary building permit or a letter of no objection from the Chief Building Surveyor. House numbers will not generally be issued except where either of these is furnished, as it is the practice of the Inland Revenue Department not to allocate house numbers to unauthorised buildings. Accordingly, the owners of the houses mentioned in the question by the hon. Member should apply to the Chief Building Surveyor for either a temporary building permit or a letter of no objection; and after obtaining same, forward them together with their applications for house numbers to the Comptroller of Property Tax, Inland Revenue Department, Property Tax Division, Government Offices, City Hall, St. Andrew's Road, Singapore. The Comptroller will then take the necessary action to number the houses.

    As regards the matter of ground rent, it can be mentioned that the Chief Building Surveyor may require production of ground rent receipts by applicants for temporary building permits or letters of no objection in order to establish the identity of the owners of the structures concerned.

NATIONAL THEATRE
(Shows by Hong Kong stars)


    7. Mr S. V. Lingam asked the Minister for Culture and Social Affairs (a) who sponsored the recent shows by

Column: 112

Hong Kong stars at the National Theatre; (b) what was the total collection; (c) what was the total expenditure; and (d) what was the net profit.

    The Minister of State for Culture (Mr Lee Khoon Choy) (for the Minister for Culture and Social Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Hongkong movie star art troupe performances at the National Theatre were sponsored by the National Theatre Trust. The total gross takings were $170,934. Entertainment duty was $32,472.80, leaving a net taking of $146,461.20. The total expenditure was $128,622.79. The net profit to the National Theatre Trust was $17,838.41.

    Mr Chow Chiok Hock (Ulu Pandan): Supplementary question, Sir. (In Mandarin): I would like to ask the Minister concerned if he can tell us whether, before the Hongkong stars came to Singapore to stage a show, anybody was sent to Hongkong to negotiate with them, how much was the expense, and who was responsible for this expense.

    Mr Lee Khoon Choy: Mr Speaker, Sir, the local agent, acting on behalf of the Hongkong movie stars art troupe, was the Grand Art Film Company. The financial arrangements with the local agent were that out of the net profit, the share to the Trust was 25 per cent and that to the Company was 75 per cent. The Company was responsible, out of the 75 per cent share of profit, for the payment to the Hongkong stars for their performances as well as payment of income tax payable on such earnings. The total expenditure figure given in answer to the Member for Aljunied has taken into account the 75 per cent share paid to the Grand Art Film Company. All these arrangements were agreed to by the National Theatre Trust.

PALMER ROAD KAMPONG
(Steps to improve inadequate drainage)


    8. Mr P. Govindaswamy asked the Minister for Law and National Development whether he is aware that the drainage in the kampong at Palmer Road is inadequate and if he will take steps to improve it.

Column: 113



    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development (Mr Ho Cheng Choon) (for the Minister for Law and National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, the kampong at Palmer Road is situated in a low-lying area, in some places more than 3 feet below road level, and is subject to tidal influence. As such, it is impossible to improve the drainage in the kampong, short of re-developing the whole kampong.

    This area will be affected by the future extension of Shenton Way to the East Wharf Reclamation, and when that takes place the kampong may have to be removed.

KAMPONG KEMBANGAN
(Priority for rural development projects)


    9. Inche Mohd. Ariff Bin Suradi asked the Minister for Law and National Development whether the Government will give first priority to requests for rural development projects, such as the improvement of roads, drainage, street-lighting and other public amenities for the Kampong Kembangan Constituency.

    Mr Ho Cheng Choon (for the Minister for Law and National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, priority is usually given to projects that are urgently required. On this basis each request from the Kampong Kembangan Constituency for improvement of roads, drainage, street lighting, and other public amenities will be considered.

    Inche Mohd. Ariff (Kampong Kembangan)(In Malay): Can the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development say what are the types of projects which are considered as urgently required?

    Mr Ho Cheng Choon: The urgent projects which require immediate attention are, for example, a road which is in a very bad condition, having a lot of pot-holes, and usually Government will give this their immediate attention.

MAKING UP OF JALAN SENANG,
JALAN LAPANG, JALAN SENYUM
AND JALAN SELAMAT


    10. Inche Mohd. Ariff Bin Suradi asked the Minister for Law and National Development when will Jalan Senang, Jalan Lapang, Jalan Senyum and Jalan Selamat be made up.

    Mr Ho Cheng Choon (for the Minister for Law and National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer is:

    (a) Tenders will soon be called for to make up Jalan Senang under section 19 of the Local Government Integration Ordinance, and it is expected that work will commence within the next three months.

    (b) Jalan Lapang and Jalan Selamat have both been included in the list of roads to be made up under section 19 of the Local Government Integration Ordinance. However, as the frontages are not yet well developed, these roads have been given low priority and may not be made up until 1968.

    (c) Jalan Senyum has been approved for making up under section 19 of the Local Government Integration Ordinance. Plans are now being prepared and notices will be served on frontagers when the plans and specifications are ready. It is expected that the work will commence early next year.

PEDESTRIAN CROSSINGS NEAR
TAMPINES CIRCUS
(Easing of traffic congestion and construction of overhead bridge)


    11. Mr R. A. Gonzales asked the Minister for Law and National Development what steps are being taken to ease the traffic congestion at the two pedestrian crossings near the Tampines Circus and whether any steps are being taken to construct an overhead bridge for pedestrians at this locality.

    Mr Ho Cheng Choon (for the Minister for Law and National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Public Works Department is in the process of widening Upper Serangoon Road, from Woodsville junction to Ponggol Road. The work now being carried out will

Column: 115

eventually improve traffic conditions near and around Tampines Circus.

    At present, no steps are being taken to construct a pedestrian overhead bridge near Tampines Circus. Consideration, however, will be given to building such a bridge if, after Upper Serangoon Road has been widened, traffic congestion still exists.

TANJONG KATONG ROAD
(Flood alleviation)


    12. Mr Ng Yeow Chong asked the Minister for Law and National Development whether he is aware that during the monsoon season practically the whole area along Tanjong Katong Road is flooded, and whether the Government has any plan to alleviate the situation.

    Mr Ho Cheng Choon (for the Minister for Law and National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not aware that the whole area along Tanjong Katong Road is flooded during the monsoon season. It is possible that an area bounded by Tanjong Katong Road, Mountbatten Road, and Wareham Road, being below high tide level, is subject to flooding during certain seasons of the year. Action has, in fact, been taken to provide a reservoir with pumping stations at Poole Road and Wimbourne Road, adjacent to the Geylang River, to deal with normal flooding situations, but the flooding cannot be prevented at all times because of the pumping capacity of the pumping stations. In any case, such flooding, when it occurs, is temporary and is not of a serious nature. It is, therefore, considered that huge sums of public funds should not be spent on relieving the minor flooding situations affecting a small area such as this.

    Mr Ho Cheng Choon (for the Minister for Law and National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer to the question is yes. The demolition of the obstructing row of shop-houses is necessary for the widening of Upper Serangoon Road now in progress. The

CHENG SAN ROAD
(Metalling)
